docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court ruling yesterday that states can be sued for violating their employees' right to time off for family emergencies. The vote in Nevada Department of Human Resources v. Hibbs was 6 to 3. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion; Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote a dissent. The full text is available online at nytimes.com/washington. FROM THE DECISION By Chief Justice Rehnquist For over a century now, we have made clear that the Constitution does not provide for federal jurisdiction over suits against nonconsenting states.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''1 in 5 Teenagers Has Sex Before 15, Study Finds'' (news article, May 20): Parents should not just have The Talk. They should have an Ongoing Conversation.
docs.abstract: Carol Weston letter suggests parents must have more than 'the talk' with teens; rather, ongoing conversation is vital to inform and protect them against perils of underage sex (May 20 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article last Monday about increased use of a drug that can prevent pregnancy within several days after sex misstated the position of the American Life League on making it available over the counter. The group, which opposes abortion and birth control, said it was not petitioning against an application for over-the-counter sales. But it did not disclaim plans to oppose approval.
docs.abstract: Correction of May 19 article: American Life League says it is not petitioning against bid for over-the-counter sales of drug that can prevent pregnancy within several days after sex; does not disclaim plans to oppose bid

docs.lead_paragraph: Maleka, a birdlike woman of 30 with a wizened face, lay on the floor on a flat cushion, wrapped in a woolen shawl. Hours earlier, she had given birth to her sixth child, who, like three others before him, had not survived. Afghanistan has among the world's highest rates of both infant mortality and maternal death because of difficulties during pregnancy or during childbirth. In this poor farming village in the Panjshir Valley northeast of the capital, Kabul, the death of Maleka's son was not unusual.

headline.main: Afghan Motherhood in a Fight for Survival

docs.abstract: Afghanistan has one of world's highest rates of infant mortality and the highest rate of maternal death because of difficulties during pregnancy or during childbirth; millions of women across rural Afghanistan live in constant cycle of pregnancy and birth through most of their adult lives with little or no medical care; it is not uncommon to meet mothers of 10 or 15 children, and they seem old before their time from physical strain; combination of poor health and nutrition, lack of skilled medical care, remoteness of their villages and cultural traditions that forbid women to see male doctors all takes a toll on women and their children; map; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Has it really been nine years, ''E.R.''? In 1994, you seduced us with your novel blend of speed and realism, your dizzying medical patter. You were the one; you earned your sky-high ratings. But as with any long-term relationship, we know you so much better now: your character flaws, your continuity problems. It's easy to take a show like you for granted, to focus on your bad habits. But I'd like to take this moment to rededicate my love -- not despite, but because of, all the ways you've changed. Do I sound deluded? Perhaps I do. Love is like that. Certainly, plenty of critics have blasted this NBC show's recent seasons, accused it of ''jumping the shark'' (a maddening phrase that encourages viewers to watch television as if we were truant officers, expecting our charges to misbehave at any minute.) The series has abandoned the medical focus of its early seasons, carpers charge. Even the former cast member George Clooney chimed in a few years back, complaining that the show's light touch had turned gimmicky and manipulative.

headline.main: Look, Mom: I'm Dating a Whole Bunch of Doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: The Court of Appeals has ruled that courts cannot use child-neglect laws to protect a fetus. The case began when a county human services department asked a court to intervene in the welfare of an unborn baby on the grounds that the mother was using methamphetamines. The state district judge would not do so on the grounds that state law applied just to dependent and neglected children younger than 18, not unborn children. The Court of Appeals agreed, stating that the law protects children only after birth. The baby in the case is living with his mother. Mindy Sink (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Neglect Laws For Fetus

docs.abstract: Colorado Court of Appeals rules courts cannot use child-neglect laws to protect fetuses because state law does not apply to unborn children; human services dept seeked to intervene in case of mother who was using methamphetamines during her pregnancy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's May 16 column about obstetric fistulas in Africa sheds light on a terrible scourge. But he takes an unjustified swipe when he speculates that the ''issue doesn't galvanize women's groups because fistulas relate to a traditional child-bearing role.''
docs.abstract: Katha Pollitt letter praises Nicholas D Kristof's May 16 column for shedding light on scourge of obstetric fistulas but rejects charge that issue does not galvanize women's groups because it relates to traditional child-bearing role

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums * ''ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).
